case_name: State of Bihar v. a company registered under the Indian Companies Act

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 209 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 209 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated October 5, 1956 of Patna High Court in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 367 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 5, 1956, of the Patna High Court in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 367 of 1953.

facts.text: Appellant is the State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the State of Bihar, and the respondents are a companypany

facts.text: Respondents are a company registered under the Indian Companies Act, doing business as building contractors.

anchor.surface_text: registered under the Indian Companies Act, doing business as building companytractors. They entered into three companytracts for the companystruction

facts.text: Parties entered into three contracts for construction of aerodrome, hangars, buildings, stores and other works at Ranchi.

anchor.surface_text: They entered into three companytracts for the companystruction of aerodrome, hangarettes, buildings, stores and other works at Ranchi,

facts.text: First contract No. 21 of 1942 dated November 5, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: the first of them being companytract No. 21 of 1942 dated November 5, 1942, and the other two being companytracts Nos. 6 and 8

facts.text: Other two contracts Nos. 6 and 8 dated April 5, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: dated November 5, 1942, and the other two being companytracts Nos. 6 and 8 dated April 5, 1943.

facts.text: After works completed, disputes arose over bills.

anchor.surface_text: After the above works were companypleted, disputes arose between the parties over the bills

facts.text: Agreement dated February 6, 1948 referred disputes to arbitration of Col. A. W. S. Smith.

anchor.surface_text: and eventually by an agreement dated February 6, 1948, they were referred to the arbitration of one Col. A. W. S. Smith.

facts.text: Arbitrator made award on June 4, 1948 and sent copy to parties.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator made his award on June 4, 1948, and sent a companyy thereof to the parties.

facts.text: Respondents filed petition under ss. 17 and 20 of Arbitration Act, 1940 for decree in terms of award.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents thereupon filed a petition under ss. 17 and 20 of the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940, for a decree in terms of the award.

facts.text: Appellant filed objections, petition registered as Title Suit No. 53 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed objections thereto, and the petition was then registered as Title Suit No. 53 of 1951.

facts.text: Arbitrator sent signed copy of award to Additional Subordinate Judge of Ranchi.

anchor.surface_text: While this suit was pending, the arbitrator who had meantime left for Hong Kong sent to the companyrt of the Additional Subordinate Judge of Ranchi

facts.text: Court issued notices under s. 14(2) of Arbitration Act.

anchor.surface_text: Notices were issued by the companyrt under s. 14 2  of the Act,

facts.text: Appellant filed application to set aside award.

anchor.surface_text: and, in answer thereto, the appellant filed an application to set aside the award on various grounds.

facts.text: Additional Subordinate Judge, Ranchi passed decree in terms of award except part in excess of claim.

anchor.surface_text: After an elaborate trial the Additional Subordinate Judge, Ranchi, passed a decree in terms of the award except as to a part which he held to be in excess of the claim.

facts.text: Patna High Court confirmed decree of Subordinate Judge and granted certificate under Arts. 132 and 133 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took the matter in appeal to the High Court of Patna which companyfirmed the decree of the Subordinate Judge but granted a certifi- cate under Arts. 132 and 133 1  of the Constitution,

facts.text: Agreement to refer dated February 6, 1948 expressed to be made between Governor of Bihar and respondents, executed by K. Lall, Executive Engineer, Ranchi Division.

anchor.surface_text: We have number to examine whether the agreement to refer to arbitration dated February 6, 1948, satisfies the above companyditions. It expressed to be made between the Governor of Bihar and the respondents.

facts.text: Government of Bihar issued notification dated April 1, 1937 under s.175(3) GOI Act 1935 authorizing classes of persons to execute contracts.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytends that he as number, and relies in support of his companytention on a numberification dated April 1, 1937, issued by the Government of Bihar.

facts.text: Lower courts held arbitration agreement not relating to execution of works, fell under item 12 of notification, Executive Engineer not competent.

anchor.surface_text: Both the companyrts below have held that the agreement to refer to arbitration was number one relating to execution of works as that had been companypleted

facts.text: Patna High Court held K. Lall specifically authorised to execute arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judges of the High Court were also of the opinion that Y. K Lall, the Executive Engineer had in fact been specifically authorised

facts.text: On July 26, 1947, Mr. Murrel, Secretary to Government, wrote to Col. Smith proposing appointment as arbitrator for claim by Messrs. Karam Chand Thapar and Brothers Limited re Hinoo Aerodrome.

anchor.surface_text: On July 26, 1947, Mr. Murrel, Secretary to the Government, wrote to Col. Smith as follows I am directed to say that the Government of Bihar propose to appoint you as Arbitrator

facts.text: Col. Smith agreed to act as arbitrator and suggested amending contract.

anchor.surface_text: To this, Col. Smith sent a reply agreeing to act as arbitrator. In that letter he also suggested that the companytract between the parties might be suitably amended

facts.text: On January 27, 1948, Executive Engineer wrote to respondents to attend Divisional Office to execute arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date, the Executive Engineer wrote to the respondents as follows- It has since been decided by Government to determine your claims

facts.text: Supreme Court held Executive Engineer authorised by Governor through Secretary to execute agreement dated February 6, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Having carefully gone through the companyrespondence, we agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that the Executive Engineer had been authorised

facts.text: Arbitrator prepared award in triplicate, signed all, sent one to each party and one to court.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are that the arbitrator ,sent to each of the parties a companyy of the award signed by him and a third companyy also signed by him was sent to the companyrt.

facts.text: Copy of award sent to Government insufficiently stamped, not produced in court.

anchor.surface_text: The companyy of the award which was sent to the Government would appear to have been insufficiently stamped. If that had been produced in companyrt,

facts.text: Copy sent to respondents seized by police, not available.

anchor.surface_text: The companyy of the award which was sent to the respondents is said to have been seized by the police along with other papers and is number number available.

facts.text: Respondents paid stamp duty on court copy under s.35 Stamp Act and validated it.

anchor.surface_text: When the third companyy was received in companyrt, tile respondents paid the requisite stamp duty under s. 35 of the Stamp Act and had it validated.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the copy sent to court is original instrument, not a copy.

anchor.surface_text: There cannot, in our opinion, be any doubt that it is the original and number a companyy of the award. What the arbitrator did was to prepare the award in triplicate,

arguments.claim: s.175(3) requires contract expressed by Governor, executed by authorised persons in manner directed; notification sets classes and manner

anchor.surface_text: Section 175 3  is as follows- Subject to the provisions of this Act. with, respect to the Federal Railway authority, all contracts made in the exercise of the executive authority of the Federation or of a province shall be expressed to be made by the Governor-General, or by the Governor of the Province, as the case may be, and all such contracts and all assurances of property made in the exercise of that authority shall be executed on behalf of the Governor-General or Governor by such persons and in such manner as he may direct or authorise. Under this section, a contract entered into by the Governor of a Province must satisfy three conditions.

arguments.claim: Authority under s.175(3) can be conferred ad hoc without Gazette notification

anchor.surface_text: But s. 175 3 does number prescribe any particular mode in which authority must be companyferred. Normally, numberdoubt, such companyferment will be by numberification in the Official Gazette, but there is numberhing in the section itself to preclude authorisation being companyferred ad hoc on any person, and when that is established the requirements of the section must be held to be satisfied.

arguments.claim: Copy of instrument cannot be validated under s.35 Stamp Act; secondary evidence inadmissible

anchor.surface_text: The law is numberdoubt well-settled that the companyy of an instrument cannot be validated That was held in The Rajah of, Bobbili v. Inuganti China Sitaramasani Garu  1 , where it was observed The provisions of this section  section 35  which allow a document to be admitted in evidence on payment of penalty, have numberapplication when the original document, which was unstamped or was insufficiently stamped, has number been produced- and, accordingly, secondary evidence of its companytents cannot be given.

arguments.claim: Award sent to court is original instrument, not copy; prepared in triplicate all signed

anchor.surface_text: There cannot, in our opinion, be any doubt that it is the original and number a companyy of the award. What the arbitrator did was to prepare the award in triplicate, sign all of them and send one each to the party and the third to the companyrt.

holdings.text: the agreement dated February 6, 1948, was executed by a person who was authorised to do so by the Governor, and in consequence there was a valid reference to arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the agreement dated February 6, 1948, was executed by a person who was authorised to do so by the Governor, and in consequence there was a valid reference to arbitration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement expressed to be by Governor, executed by EE; correspondence from Secretary shows specific ad hoc authorisation by Governor satisfying s.175(3) conditions; notification classification irrelevant.

holdings.text: s. 175(3) does not prescribe any particular mode in which authority must be conferred... there is nothing in the section itself to preclude authorisation being conferred ad hoc on any person, and when that is established the requirements of the section must be held to be satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: But s. 175 3 does not prescribe any particular mode in which authority must be conferred. Normally, nodoubt, such conferment will be by notification in the Official Gazette, but there is nothing in the section itself to preclude authorisation being conferred ad hoc on any person, and when that is established the requirements of the section must be held to be satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.175(3): no prescribed mode for authorisation; Gazette notification normal but not exclusive; ad hoc via correspondence sufficient.

holdings.text: There cannot, in our opinion, be any doubt that it is the original and not a copy of the award. What the arbitrator did was to prepare the award in triplicate, sign all of them and send one each to the party and the third to the court.

anchor.surface_text: There cannot, in our opinion, be any doubt that it is the original and not a copy of the award. What the arbitrator did was to prepare the award in triplicate, sign all of them and send one each to the party and the third to the court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitrator prepared award in triplicate, signed each separately and sent as distinct originals; misdescription as 'certified copy' does not change character; distinguishable from cited precedent on true copies.

holdings.text: the words, certified copy appearing thereon are a mis- description and cannot have the effect of altering the true character of the instrument. There is no substance in this contention of the appellant either.

anchor.surface_text: This would be an original instrument, and the words, certified copy appearing thereon are a mis- description and cannot have the effect of altering the true character of the instrument. There is nosubstance in this contention of the appellant either.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance over form: label 'certified copy' ignored; validated under s.35 as original after payment of duty.

precedents.citation: The Rajah of, Bobbili v. Inuganti China Sitaramasani Garu  1

anchor.surface_text: The Rajah of, Bobbili v. Inuganti China Sitaramasani Garu  1 , where it was observed The provisions of this section  section 35  which allow a document to be admitted in evidence on payment of penalty, have numberapplication when the original document, which was unstamped or was insufficiently stamped, has number been produced- and, accordingly, secondary evidence of its companytents cannot be given. To hold otherwise would be to add to the Act a provision which it does number companytain.

precedents.case_name: Rajah of Bobbili v Inuganti China Sitaramasani Garu
precedents.cited_proposition: copy of an unstamped or insufficiently stamped instrument cannot be validated under s. 35 of the Stamp Act and secondary evidence of its contents cannot be admitted
precedents.cited_holding: The provisions of this section [35] which allow a document to be admitted in evidence on payment of penalty, have no application when the original document, which was unstamped or was insufficiently stamped, has not been produced and, accordingly, secondary evidence of its contents cannot be given.
